articles.title: When 'a few degrees' Becomes Dangerous - Living with Extreme Heat
articles.author: Jamil Wyne
articles.summary: According to WHO, from 2000 to 2019 nearly half a million people died annually from heat exposure. According to IPCC, even a rise of 1.5°C in global average temperatures transforms local realities. Heatwaves that used to occur once a century will strike roughly every five years. The relationship between global averages and local extremes is nonlinear and even small changes in global averages create much larger local shocks. Extreme heat touches everyone, but its impacts are unequal. For wealthy people, it's a threat to survival, for poorer ones, it means rising costs of cooling and infrastructure repair.
